item1: Eversource Energy (Eversource), headquartered Boston, Massachusetts Hartford, Connecticut, public utility holding company subject regulation Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) under Public Utility Holding Company Act 2005. engaged primarily energy delivery business through following wholly-owned utility subsidiaries: Connecticut Light Power Company (CL&P), regulated electric utility serves residential, commercial industrial customers parts Connecticut; NSTAR Electric Company (NSTAR Electric), regulated electric utility serves residential, commercial industrial customers parts eastern western Massachusetts owns solar power facilities, its wholly-owned subsidiary Harbor Electric Energy Company (HEEC), also regulated electric utility distributes electric energy its sole customer; Public Service Company New Hampshire (PSNH), regulated electric utility serves residential, commercial industrial customers parts New Hampshire; NSTAR Gas Company (NSTAR Gas), regulated natural gas utility serves residential, commercial industrial customers parts Massachusetts; Eversource Gas Company Massachusetts (EGMA), regulated natural gas utility serves residential, commercial industrial customers parts Massachusetts; Yankee Gas Services Company (Yankee Gas), regulated natural gas utility serves residential, commercial industrial customers parts Connecticut; Aquarion Company (Aquarion), utility holding company owns five separate regulated water utility subsidiaries collectively serves residential, commercial, industrial, municipal fire protection customers parts Connecticut, Massachusetts New Hampshire. Eversource currently process selling its Aquarion water distribution business. further information, see "Business Development Capital Expenditures – Pending Sale Aquarion" accompanying Item 7, Management's Discussion Analysis Financial Condition Results Operations CL&P, NSTAR Electric PSNH also serve New England customers through Eversource's electric transmission business.
item7: October 17, 2024, PURA issued proposed final decision recovery costs AMI implementation. Written exceptions proposed final decision filed October 31, 2024, oral arguments presented November 7, 2024. CL&P’s written exceptions focused three main aspects proposed decision, which include (1) clarifying prudence standard used evaluating AMI investments, (2) timing prudency reviews, (3) cost recovery related incremental O&M expenses. December 4, 2024, PURA issued final decision recovery costs AMI implementation.
